   Assessment and Plan
   71 y/o M with PMHx significant for systolic HF (EF 20-25%), MI in '[**26**],
   paroxysmal AV block, atrial fibrillation, h/o v.tach and v.fib s/p ICD
   implantation, who presented to the ED with a chief complaint of
   dyspnea, initially thought to be due to CHF exacerbation but now
   suspicious for pneumonia.
   .
   # Dyspnea: Overnight, the patient had recurrent of dyspnea. Repeat CXR
   showed a more clear left-sided infiltrate. Also, of note, pt had fevers
   overnight. This presentation now more consistent with pneumonia, with a
   possible superimposed CHF component. Pt given
   vanc/cefepime/levofloxacin yesterday evening.
   - vanc/cefepime/azithromycin for broad coverage for pneumonia
   -
   - holding on further antibiotics at this time, as pt does not
   clinically appear to have a pneumonia
   - continue metoprolol 12.5 mg daily
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt has a history of an anterior wall MI in [**2126**]. Pt
   denies any current chest pain, and the first set of CE's was negative.
   Of note, the patient did report some chest pressure last night and in
   the ED this morning, but this has since resolved.
   - will continue to rule out MI with 3 sets of CE's
   - continue to monitor for any chest pain
   .
   # RHYTHM: Pt with a history of a.fib, for which he is on coumadin. His
   INR is currently therapeutic at 2.3. Telemetry currently showing
   v-paced rhythm.
   - continue coumadin, with goal INR of 2.3
   - need to closely monitor INR, as it may change at patient received
   levofloxacin in the ED
   .
   # Hypertension: Normotensive at this time.
   - continue metoprolol tartrate
   - lasix bolus PRN
   .
   # Hypothyroidism:
   - continue levothyroxine 50 mcg daily
   .
   # Anemia: Pt with a history of anemia, baseline Hct of approx. 33-35.
   Pt currently near his baseline.
   - continue iron supplementation
   - continue to trend hct
   - bowel regimen with colace/senna
   .
   # ID: Per o/p ID notes, the patient is on chornic cefpodoxime for
   ongoing suppression after high-grade viridans streptococcal bacteremia
   in the setting of pacer/defibrillator wires and to continue intended
   life-long suppression for suspected Klebsiella pneumoniae lead
   endocarditis during a prior bacteremia.
   - continue cefpodoxime
   .
   # S/p Whipple:
   - continue pancreatic enzyme repletion
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2141-3-3**] 12:30 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: (Systemic anticoagulation: Coumadin)

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU with several medical conditions and treatments. The patient has been experiencing dyspnea and required BiPAP support. A chest X-ray revealed an infiltrate on the left side, leading to the administration of cefepime (an antibiotic) to address potential pneumonia.

The patient has allergies to penicillins and Ambien, which should be taken into consideration during medication administration. The patient is also receiving furosemide (Lasix) for an unknown reason. 

The vital signs show a fever with a maximum temperature of 38.2 degrees Celsius (100.7 degrees Fahrenheit) and an average temperature of 37.8 degrees Celsius (100.1 degrees Fahrenheit). The patient's heart rate is slightly elevated at 93 beats per minute, with a blood pressure of 104/61 mmHg. The respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and the oxygen saturation is 95%. The patient is being paced at a heart rate of 70-98 beats per minute.

The patient's fluid balance shows a net loss of 2,520 mL in 24 hours. The patient is receiving high-flow oxygen through a neb device and is on CPAP/PSV mode with a set tidal volume of 541 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 100%.

   71 y/o M with PMHx significant for systolic HF (EF 20-25%), MI in '[**26**],
   paroxysmal AV block, atrial fibrillation, h/o v.tach and v.fib s/p ICD
   implantation, who presented to the ED this morning with a chief
   complaint of dyspnea, likely due to CHF exacerbation.
   .
   # Dyspnea: Likely related to CHF exacerbation. The patient reports
   recent dietary indiscretion; BNP is ~3000. He also reports increased
   leg edema, DOE, and PND recently. He self-increased his PO lasix dose
   this week with little effect. This could have been related to decreased
   absorption of PO lasix in the setting of gut edema. He does report a
   productive cough recently, and his CXR showed a potential LLL
   opacification. However, pneumonia seems unlikely, as he does not have a
   fever or leukocytosis.
   - pt put out very well to 40 mg IV lasix in the ED; will continue to
   monitor I/O and will re-bolus when UOP declines
   - holding on further antibiotics at this time, as pt does not
   clinically appear to have a pneumonia
   - continue metoprolol 12.5 mg daily
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt has a history of an anterior wall MI in [**2126**]. Pt
   denies any current chest pain, and the first set of CE's was negative.
   Of note, the patient did report some chest pressure last night and in
   the ED this morning, but this has since resolved.
   - will continue to rule out MI with 3 sets of CE's
   - continue to monitor for any chest pain
   .

   INR is currently therapeutic at 2.3. Telemetry currently showing
   v-paced rhythm.
   - continue coumadin, with goal INR of 2.3
   - need to closely monitor INR, as it may change at patient received

The patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU for a chief complaint of dyspnea, likely due to a congestive heart failure exacerbation. The patient has also reported recent dietary indiscretion, increased leg edema, dyspnea on exertion, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He self-increased his oral lasix dose with little effect and has a B-type natriuretic peptide level of approximately 3000. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.2 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 93 beats per minute, blood pressure of 104/61 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, receiving high-flow nasal cannula oxygen, with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) set at 100%. His arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.48, PaCO2 of 37 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 80. Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient, a 71-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation, presented to the emergency department with dyspnea.
- The initial assessment suggested a possible exacerbation of congestive heart failure, but there are now signs consistent with pneumonia, possibly with a superimposed CHF component.
- The patient has been given broad-spectrum antibiotics including vancomycin, cefepime, and azithromycin, and attempts are being made to obtain sputum cultures.
- Other ongoing treatments include restarting Lasix to prevent CHF exacerbation, continuing metoprolol, and monitoring for any chest pain to rule out myocardial infarction.
- The patient's rhythm is currently ventricular-paced, and his INR is therapeutic at 2.3. Coumadin will be continued with close monitoring of INR due to potential changes with antibiotic use.
- The patient's hypertension is currently normotensive, and he will continue on metoprolol and Lasix.
- Other medical conditions such as hypothyroidism, anemia, and ID-related issues will also be managed accordingly.
- ICU care includes nutrition support, glycemic control, line management, prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcers, and monitoring for ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old male with a significant medical history of systolic heart failure (EF 20-25%), myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) implantation. The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea and was initially thought to have a congestive heart failure exacerbation but is now more consistent with pneumonia.

The patient's current conditions include hypoxemic respiratory failure/pneumonia, hypotension/sepsis, chronic systolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, s/p ICD, hypothyroidism, anemia, and chronic antibiotic use. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation for hypoxemia, receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, and being treated for hypotension with IV fluids and norepinephrine.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, septic shock, exacerbation of heart failure, arrhythmias, and further infections. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, oxygenation, fluid balance, and antibiotic therapy will be crucial in managing these potential complications.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation with an implanted cardioverter-defibrillator. The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea, initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation but now suspected to be pneumonia. Overnight, the patient had recurrent dyspnea and repeat chest X-ray showed a more clear left-sided infiltrate. The patient also had fevers overnight. This presentation is now more consistent with pneumonia, possibly with a superimposed congestive heart failure component. The patient was given vancomycin, cefepime, and levofloxacin yesterday evening. Broad-spectrum antibiotics including vancomycin, cefepime, and azithromycin were initiated for pneumonia coverage. Sputum cultures were attempted. Lasix 60 mg PO daily was restarted to prevent CHF exacerbation on top of pneumonia. Metoprolol 12.5 mg daily was continued per home medication list.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventricular arrhythmias due to the patient's history of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.
2. Pneumonia progression or worsening due to the presence of bilateral crackles and coarse breath sounds, as well as the development of fevers.
3

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a medical history of systolic heart failure, previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). He presented to the emergency department with dyspnea and was initially thought to have a congestive heart failure exacerbation with pneumonia. However, it was later determined that the patient also had a superimposed component of pneumonia with hypoxemic respiratory failure. He was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to severe hypoxemia.

The patient's current medications include vancomycin, cefepime, azithromycin for broad-spectrum coverage, levothyroxine for hypothyroidism, aspirin for coronary artery disease, and warfarin for atrial fibrillation. He also has a history of chronic antibiotic use for suppression of ongoing bacterial infections.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: The patient has been diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and is already receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics. It is important to monitor his response to the antibiotics and watch for any signs of worsening infection or development of drug-resistant organisms.
2. Sepsis: Given the patient's hypotension and elevated white blood cell count, there is a concern for sepsis, possibly secondary to the pneumonia. Close monitoring of vital signs, urine output, and organ function is necessary to

2. Sepsis: The patient is already showing signs of sepsis, including hypotension and tachycardia. If not promptly treated, sepsis can progress to severe seps

   Assessment and Plan
   71 y/o M with PMHx significant for systolic HF (EF 20-25%), MI in '[**26**],
   paroxysmal AV block, atrial fibrillation, h/o v.tach and v.fib s/p ICD
   implantation, who presented to the ED with a chief complaint of
   dyspnea, initially thought to be due to CHF exacerbation with
   infiltrate,fever, white count consistent with PNA.
   .
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure/Pneumonia: Patient with fever, cough,
   dyspnea, left-sided infiltrate on CXR. On vancomycin, cefepime,
   azithromycin for broad coverage.  Was intubated on [**3-4**] for hypoxemia.
   - continue mechanical ventilation.  Consider trial on pressure support
   if  patient becomes more alert.
   - continue vancomycin, cefepime, azithromycin.
   - f/u pending cultures (no positive micro data to date)
   - chest CT to better evaluate lung fields
   .
   # Hypotension/sepsis: Off pressors since 2 a.m. with SBP around 110.
   - holding metoprolol
   - holding diuresis
   .
   # Chronic systolic heart failure: Patient with EF 20-25%. Currently
   euvolemic.
   - holding diuresis
   - holding metoprolol in setting of hypotension
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt has a history of an anterior wall MI in [**2126**]. Of note,
   the patient did report some chest pressure previously, but this has
   since resolved.  MI ruled out with 3 sets of cardiac enzymes.
   - continue aspirin 81 mg daily
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation: Pt with a history of a.fib, for which he is on
   coumadin. His INR is currently therapeutic at 2.3 on presentation.
   Telemetry currently showing v-paced rhythm.
   - holding metoprolol in setting of hypotension; consider restarting if
   BP stable off pressors
   - holding Coumadin in setting of supratherapeutic INR
   .
   # s/p ICD: high impedance. LV lead dysfunction
   -pacer revison in future
   -if develops VT, will need external therapy as ICD is not functioning
   .
   # Hypothyroidism:
   - continue levothyroxine 50 mcg daily
   .
   # Anemia: Pt with a history of anemia, baseline Hct of approx. 33-35.
   Hct gradually trending down. No evidence of bleeding.
   - continue iron supplementation
   - continue to trend hct
   - bowel regimen with colace/senna
   .
   # Chronic antibiotic use: Per o/p ID notes, the patient is on chornic
   cefpodoxime for ongoing suppression after high-grade viridans
   streptococcal bacteremia in the setting of pacer/defibrillator wires
   and to continue intended life-long suppression for suspected Klebsiella
   pneumoniae lead endocarditis during a prior bacteremia. On cefepime per
   ID.
   - holding cefpodoxime while on broad spectrum abx as above
   .
   # S/p Whipple: On tube feeds. Holding  pancreatic enzyme repletion

Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a significant medical history including systolic heart failure, previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation. The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea and was initially thought to have a congestive heart failure exacerbation with pneumonia. However, further evaluation revealed hypoxemic respiratory failure, and the patient was intubated for hypoxemia. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics including vancomycin, cefepime, and azithromycin. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he remains hypotensive and requires vasopressors. His heart function is compromised with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. The patient also has a history of chronic antibiotic use for suppression of ongoing infections and is currently on cefepime per Infectious Disease consultation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: The patient's initial presentation suggested pneumonia, which is a common complication in ICU patients. His symptoms include fever, cough, and infiltrate on chest X-ray. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been initiated, but the patient's response to treatment should be closely monitored.

2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and elevated white blood cell count indicate a possible sepsis. This is a serious condition that can lead to organ

The patient is a 71-year-old male with a medical history of systolic heart failure, myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation, who presented to the emergency department with dyspnea. Initial assessment suggested a possible exacerbation of congestive heart failure with infiltrate and fever, but subsequent investigations revealed hypoxemic respiratory failure with atelectasis/effusion on chest CT. The patient has been intubated and is currently on mechanical ventilation. 

The patient also has chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20-25% and is hypervolemic. He has a history of an anterior wall myocardial infarction in 2016 and is currently on aspirin and simvastatin. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation for which he is taking coumadin, and his INR is currently therapeutic at 2.3. He is also on levothyroxine for hypothyroidism and iron supplementation for anemia. 

The patient has undergone Whipple's procedure and is currently on tube feeds, but pancreatic enzyme repletion has been difficult to administer through the tube.

He was admitted to the ICU due to dyspnea, initially thought to be a congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate and fever, but later diagnosed as pneumonia.

The patient's current conditions and potential complications include:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient was intubated for hypoxemia and is now requiring an increased amount of supplemental oxygen (FiO2 50%). A chest CT shows atelectasis/effusion rather than pneumonia, but the patient will complete the course of antibiotics. Mechanical ventilation will be continued.

2. Chronic systolic heart failure: The patient has a reduced ejection fraction of 20-25%. He is currently hypervolemic and will undergo diuresis with the goal of being negative 2 liters by the end of the day. Metoprolol will be restarted if tolerated, and Coumadin will be restarted with a therapeutic INR.

3. Coronaries: The patient has a history of an anterior wall myocardial infarction. His chest pressure has resolved, and three sets of cardiac enzymes have ruled out a new myocardial infarction. Aspirin and simvastatin will be continued.

4. Atrial fibrillation:

   71 y/o M with PMHx significant for systolic HF (EF 20-25%), MI in '[**26**],
   paroxysmal AV block, atrial fibrillation, h/o v.tach and v.fib s/p ICD
   implantation, who presented to the ED with a chief complaint of
   dyspnea, initially thought to be due to CHF exacerbation with
   infiltrate, fever, white count consistent with PNA.
   .
   # Elevated CK: Pt noted to have an elevated in CK on labwork yesterday.
   Not likely cardiac in nature, as MB is normal. Serotonin syndrome is a
   possibility in this patient on fentanyl and with high fevers. However,
   physical exam not consistent with serotonin syndrome. Also, the patient
   has been on fentanyl for some time, and you would expect this to have
   shown up sooner. Likely this is mild rhabdomyolysis in the setting of
   prolonged hospitalization and sedation. Pt was given 500 cc overnight
   to help prevent renal damage from the elevated CK. CK trending down
   this morning.
   - continue to trend CK
   - no further IV fluids at this point, as CK not at a significant enough
   level to cause renal failure
   - holding statin
   .
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure:  Was intubated on [**3-4**] for hypoxemia.
   Chest CT more consistent with atelectasis/effusion rather than
   pneumonia.  Oxygenation improving.  Right side clearing
   radiographically as of yesterday.  Suspect multifactorial etiology of
   CHF + pneumonia. Of note, pt spiked high temperatures yesterday despite
   being on vanc/cefepime/flagyl. Started on a cooling blanket and
   switched to meropenem
   - continue mechanical ventilation, with daily spontaneous breathing
   trials
   - continue meropenem monotherapy
   - f/u pending cultures (no positive micro data to date)
   - consider bronch today
   .
   # Fever: Likely source is pneumonia, although differential includes
   worsening of known ICD infection. Unclear why patient is continuing to

The patient was intubated due to hypoxemic respiratory failure and is currently on mechanical ventilation. Fever, elevated white blood cell count, and positive blood cultures indicate a possible hospital-acquired infection, leading to the decision to switch to meropenem monotherapy.

This could be due to rhabdomyolysis in the setting of prolonged hospitalization and sedation. The patient received 500 cc of fluids overnight to prevent renal damage from the elevated CK. CK is trending down this morning.
2. Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated for hypoxemia and is currently on mechanical ventilation. Oxygenation is improving, and there is suspicion of multifactorial etiology of CHF + pneumonia. The patient's chest CT shows atelectasis/effusion rather than pneumonia.
3. Fever: The patient continues to have fevers despite being on broad-spectrum antibiotics. The likely source of fever is pneumonia, but other potential causes include worsening of known ICD infection.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation who presented to the emergency department with dyspnea. The initial assessment suggested a possible congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia.

The patient was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure and started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. However, the patient continued to spike fevers, leading to a switch in antibiotics to meropenem. The chest CT showed atelectasis/effusion rather than pneumonia, and the patient's oxygenation is improving. The patient's elevated CK levels were noted, and further investigation is ongoing to determine the cause, with possibilities including serotonin syndrome, rhabdomyolysis, or renal damage.

The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20-25% and is currently hypervolemic. Lasix was administered to promote diuresis. The patient also has a history of hyperglycemia, which may be due to infection or medication infusion in D5W. Insulin sliding scale and basal insulin were initiated.

The patient has a history of an anterior wall myocardial infarction, and his coronary arteries are currently being managed with aspirin, simvastatin

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) implantation. He presented to the emergency department with dyspnea and was initially thought to have congestive heart failure exacerbation with pneumonia. However, the chest CT showed atelectasis/effusion rather than pneumonia. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. He has been diagnosed with hypoxemic respiratory failure, chronic systolic heart failure, fever (likely due to pneumonia), hyperglycemia (possibly related to infection or medication), and anemia (with a baseline Hct of 33-35%). The patient also has a history of atrial fibrillation and is on coumadin with subtherapeutic INR levels. His ICD is currently not functioning properly due to high impedance and LV lead dysfunction. The patient is also being treated for chronic antibiotic use, s/p Whipple's procedure, and has a history of hypothyroidism.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is on mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and central venous catheters increase the risk of DVT.
3. Stress ulcers: The patient is at risk of developing stress ulcers due

Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a medical history of systolic heart failure (ejection fraction 20-25%), previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation with an implanted cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). He presented to the emergency department with dyspnea and was initially thought to have a congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white blood count consistent with pneumonia.

The patient was intubated on day 3 for hypoxemia and chest CT showed atelectasis/effusion rather than pneumonia. Oxygenation has been improving, with right-sided clearing radiographically. The patient's condition is suspected to be multifactorial, involving both congestive heart failure and pneumonia.

The patient's current medications include vancomycin, cefepime, Flagyl, aspirin, simvastatin, metoprolol, and levothyroxine. He is also on chronic cefpodoxime for ongoing suppression after high-grade viridans streptococcal bacteremia in the setting of pacer/defibrillator wires and to continue intended life-long suppression for suspected Klebsiella pneumoniae lead endocarditis during a prior bacteremia. However, the cefpodoxime is being held while on broad-spectrum antibiotics as above.

The patient's vital signs include a

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation who presented to the emergency department with dyspnea. He was initially thought to have a congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia. The patient was intubated on day 3 for hypoxemia, likely due to pneumonia and heart failure. His respiratory status has been improving clinically and radiographically. The main barrier to extubation is sedation.

The patient continues to experience fever despite Tylenol, antibiotics, and improvement in respiratory status. The source of the fever is unclear, and further investigations such as CT abdomen/pelvis and CT sinuses are planned. The patient's chronic systolic heart failure is being managed with close monitoring of fluid status, continued metoprolol, and holding diuretics today.

The patient's elevated creatine kinase (CK) level is likely caused by statin therapy, possibly exacerbated by concurrent azithromycin therapy. The CK is trending down, and no further IV fluids are being given at this point as CK is not at a significant enough level to cause renal failure. The statin therapy is being held.

The patient also has hyperglycemia without a known history of diabetes. Contributing factors include stress response

There are pending cultures, and a bronchoscopy is being considered.

The patient continues to spike fevers despite being on antibiotics, which raises concerns for empyema or other sources of infection. The patient's elevated creatine kinase (CK) level is likely due to rhabdomyolysis secondary to prolonged hospitalization and sedation, rather than cardiac or serotonin syndrome-related causes. Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a significant medical history including systolic heart failure (ejection fraction 20-25%), previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) implantation. He presented to the emergency department with complaints of dyspnea, initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia.

The patient was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The etiology of respiratory failure is likely pneumonia combined with heart failure. His respiratory status has improved clinically and radiographically. The main barrier to extubation is sedation. He underwent bronchoscopy and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) on [**2141-3-11**].

The patient continues to have high fevers in spite of Tylenol, antibiotics, and improvement in respiratory status. The source of fever is unclear. The attending ID physician recommends further investigations including CT abdomen/pelvis and CT sinuses. He will continue on meropenem monotherapy, follow ID recommendations, and await pending microbiological studies.

The patient has chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. He is currently euvolemic to hypovolemic. Monitoring fluid

   Assessment and Plan
   71 y/o M with PMHx significant for systolic HF (EF 20-25%), MI in '[**26**],
   paroxysmal AV block, atrial fibrillation, h/o v.tach and v.fib s/p ICD
   implantation, who presented to the ED with a chief complaint of
   dyspnea, initially thought to be due to CHF exacerbation with
   infiltrate, fever, white count consistent with PNA.
   .
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure:  Was intubated on [**3-4**] for hypoxemia.
   Etiology likely pneumonia + heart failure. Respiratory status improving
   clinically and radiographically. Main barrier to extubation is
   sedation.  s/p bronchoscopy/BAL [**2141-3-11**].
   - continue mechanical ventilation, with daily spontaneous breathing
   trials
   - too sedated on exam this morning, will defer extubation
   - continue meropenem monotherapy
   - f/u pending cultures (no positive micro data to date)
   .
   # Fever: Source unclear. Initially attributed to pneumonia, but patient
   has continued to spike high fevers in spite of Tylenol, antibiotics,
   and improvement in respiratory status. ID following. CT abd/pelvis and
   CT sinuses were negative by prelim read.
   - continue meropenem monotherapy
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u pending microbiological studies
   .
   # Chronic systolic heart failure: Patient with EF 20-25%. Currently
   euvolemic to hypovolemic.
   - continue to monitor fluid status
   - continue metoprolol [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Elevated CK: Likely caused by stain (possibly exacerbated by
   concurrent azithromycin therapy).  CK trending down.
   - continue to trend CK
   - no further IV fluids at this point, as CK not at a significant enough
   level to cause renal failure
   - holding statin
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: No known history of diabetes. Contributing factors
   include stress response to infection, h/o pancreatic resection,
   infusion of meds in D5W.
   - insulin sliding scale
   - continue basal insulin
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt has a history of an anterior wall MI in [**2126**]. Of note,
   the patient did report some chest pressure previously, but this has
   since resolved.  MI ruled out with 3 sets of cardiac enzymes.
   - continue aspirin, simvastatin, metoprolol
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation: Pt with a history of a.fib, for which he is on
   coumadin. His INR is currently subtherapeutic. Telemetry currently
   showing v-paced rhythm.
   - metoprolol [**Hospital1 7**]
   - continue Coumadin; trend INR
   - heparin SQ for DVT ppx while subtherapeutic INR
   .
   # s/p ICD: high impedance. LV lead dysfunction
   -pacer revison in future
   -if develops VT, will need external therapy as ICD is not functioning
   .
   # Hypothyroidism:
   - continue levothyroxine 50 mcg daily
   .
   # Anemia: Pt with a history of anemia, baseline Hct of approx. 33-35.
   Hct gradually trending down. No evidence of bleeding.
   - continue iron supplementation
   - continue to trend hct
   .
   # S/p Whipple: On tube feeds.
   - Holding pancreatic enzyme supplementation while on tube feeds.

   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 71-year-old male with a significant medical history including systolic heart failure (ejection fraction 20-25%), previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation after implantation of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea and was initially thought to have a congestive heart failure exacerbation with pneumonia. He was intubated for hypoxemia and received bronchoscopy and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL). 

The patient has been on mechanical ventilation with daily spontaneous breathing trials. He is being treated with meropenem monotherapy for suspected pneumonia. Despite improvement in respiratory status, the patient continues to have high fevers, and the source of fever is unclear. Imaging studies have been ordered to investigate further. 

The patient also has chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. He is euvolemic to hypovolemic. His fluid status is being closely monitored, and diuretics are being held. 

The patient's elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels are likely caused by statin therapy, possibly exacerbated by concurrent azithromycin therapy. The CK levels are trending down. 

Hyperglycemia is present, possibly due to the stress response to infection, history

Summary:

He presented to the emergency department with dyspnea, initially thought to be due to a congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient was intubated for hypoxemia, and the etiology is likely pneumonia and heart failure. His respiratory status has improved clinically and radiographically, but sedation remains a barrier to extubation.
2. Fever: The source of the fever is unclear. It was initially attributed to pneumonia, but the patient continues to spike high fevers despite Tylenol, antibiotics, and improvement in respiratory status. The ID team is following up, and pending cultures are being monitored.
3. Chronic systolic heart failure: The patient has an ejection fraction of 20-25%. His fluid status is being closely monitored, and he is currently euvolemic to hypovolemic. Metoprolol therapy is continued.
4. Elevated CK: The elevated creatine kinase (CK) level is likely caused by statin therapy (possibly exacerbated by concurrent azithrom

The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea, initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia.

The patient was intubated for hypoxemia and is currently mechanically ventilated. The etiology of respiratory failure is likely pneumonia combined with heart failure. The patient continues to have fever, and the source is unclear. Initially, it was attributed to pneumonia, but the patient has continued to spike high fevers despite Tylenol, antibiotics, and improvement in respiratory status. Infection control is being followed, and a CT abdomen/pelvis and CT sinuses were negative by preliminary read.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a medical history of systolic heart failure, previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, and ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation treated with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea and was initially thought to be experiencing a congestive heart failure exacerbation with pneumonia. However, the source of fever remains unclear as it continues despite antibiotics and improvement in respiratory status. The patient has been intubated due to hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely caused by pneumonia and heart failure. There are concerns about lead endocarditis given the patient's history of ICD implantation. The patient's systolic heart failure is being managed with careful fluid balance and diuretics. Elevated CK levels are attributed to a recent stain and are trending down. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and previous anterior wall myocardial infarction. Telemetry shows a ventricular-paced rhythm, and the patient's INR is subtherapeutic. The patient's ICD is not functioning properly, with high impedance and left ventricular lead dysfunction. There are also issues related to hypothyroidism, anemia, and complications from previous Whipple's surgery. The patient is receiving appropriate ICU care, including nutrition support, glycemic control, and prophylaxis

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation who presented to the emergency department with dyspnea. He was initially thought to have a congestive heart failure exacerbation with pneumonia but has continued to spike high fevers despite receiving Tylenol, antibiotics, and improvement in respiratory status. The patient's condition has been complicated by cardiac arrest, hypoxemic respiratory failure, chronic systolic heart failure, elevated creatine kinase levels, coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, implantable cardioverter-defibrillator dysfunction, hypothyroidism, anemia, and a history of Whipple's disease.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient has persistent fevers and is being investigated for potential intracardiac source of infection, which could indicate infective endocarditis or another type of infection.
2. Ventricular arrhythmia: The patient experienced a ventricular fibrillation during the code blue event, and the ICD did not terminate it. This highlights the risk of recurrent ventricular arrhythmias, which may require external therapy since the ICD is not functioning properly.
3. Chronic systolic heart failure: The patient's baseline ejection fraction is 20-25%, indicating severe systolic dysfunction. Management of chronic heart failure

Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a medical history of systolic heart failure (ejection fraction 20-25%), previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) implantation. The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of dyspnea, initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white blood count consistent with pneumonia.

The patient has been admitted to the ICU and has been intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure. The etiology of the respiratory failure is likely pneumonia and heart failure. The patient's respiratory status has been improving clinically and radiographically, but sedation remains a barrier to extubation.

The patient's condition is further complicated by several other medical issues. There is an ongoing fever of unknown origin, which has not resolved despite antibiotics and improvement in respiratory status. The source of the fever remains unclear. Imaging studies such as CT abdomen/pelvis and CT sinuses have been negative.

The patient also has elevated cardiac enzymes, suggesting possible myocardial injury or ischemia. However, three sets of cardiac enzymes have ruled out a new myocardial infarction. The patient's ICD is not functioning properly due to high impedance, likely caused by lead dysfunction.

The patient's INR is subtherapeutic,

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a medical history significant for systolic heart failure, myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation. The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea and was initially thought to have a congestive heart failure exacerbation with pneumonia. However, the patient continued to spike high fevers despite antibiotics and improvement in respiratory status. A CT abdomen/pelvis and CT sinuses were negative. The patient has been afebrile for 24 hours and has a positive blood culture (GPC positive) this morning. This could represent true infection or contaminant.

The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure improved clinically and radiographically, leading to intubation on [**3-4**]. The etiology is likely pneumonia and heart failure. The patient's mental status greatly improved this morning, and the RSBI is in the 30s. It is planned to attempt extubation after transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) and to follow pending cultures and bronchoscopic data.

The patient has chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. He has been diuresing well to lasix boluses. It is planned to continue monitoring fluid status, continue metoprolol, and give 60 mg IV lasix now.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 71-year-old male with a medical history of systolic heart failure (ejection fraction 20-25%), myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placement. The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea, initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia.

The patient continues to spike high fevers despite Tylenol, antibiotics, and improvement in respiratory status. Imaging studies such as CT abdomen/pelvis and CT sinuses were negative. The patient's ICD did not shock during code blue yesterday.

The patient was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely due to pneumonia and heart failure. Respiratory status is improving clinically and radiographically. The main barrier to extubation has been sedation.

The patient has chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. Fluid status is euvolemic to hypovolemic. The patient's creatine kinase (CK) level is elevated but trending down, likely caused by statin therapy. The CK level is not at a significant enough level to cause renal failure.

The patient has a history of anterior wall myocardial infarction in [**2126**]. The patient reported some chest pressure previously, but this has since resolved. Myocardial infarction has been ruled out with 3 sets of cardiac enzymes.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation for which he is on warfarin. His international normalized ratio (INR) is currently subtherapeutic. Telemetry currently shows ventricular-paced rhythm.

The patient underwent Whipple procedure and is on tube feeds. Pancreatic enzyme supplementation is being held while on tube feeds.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Fever: The patient continues to spike high fevers in spite of Tylenol, antibiotics, and improvement in respiratory status. The source of the fever is unclear. Further investigation is needed to determine the cause, which may include pneumonia, lead endocarditis, central nervous system infection, or drug fever.

2. Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure. Although the patient's respiratory status is improving, there is a risk of further deterioration. Daily spontaneous breathing trials should be continued to assess readiness for extubation.

3. Chronic Systolic Heart Failure: The patient has a history of systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. Fluid status is euvolemic to hypovolemic. Close monitoring of fluid status and medication adjustment, including metoprolol and lasix, should be continued.

4. Elevated CK: The patient's CK level is elevated but trending down

   Assessment and Plan
   71 y/o M with PMHx significant for systolic HF (EF 20-25%), MI in '[**26**],
   paroxysmal AV block, atrial fibrillation, h/o v.tach and v.fib s/p ICD
   implantation, who presented to the ED with a chief complaint of
   dyspnea, initially thought to be due to CHF exacerbation with
   infiltrate, fever, white count consistent with PNA.
   .
   # Fever: Now afebrile x 48 hours. Previously, patient was spiking high
   fevers in spite of Tylenol, antibiotics, and improvement in respiratory
   status. CT abd/pelvis and CT sinuses were neg. Pt has been afebrile
   over 24 hours at this point. However, he did have a positive blood cx
   (GPC
s) this am. This could represent true infection versus
   contaminant.
   - continue meropenem; adding vanc in the setting of positive blood cx
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u pending microbiological studies
   - TEE to look for ? lead endocarditis
   - will need to pull CVL in setting of positive blood cx; d/w team
   whether we should place another CVL versus try to obtain peripheral
   access until patient is able to get a PICC
   - if above is negative and pt continues to spike fevers, will need to
   consider other causes, such as CNS infx or drug fever
   .
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure:  Was intubated on [**3-4**] for hypoxemia.
   Etiology likely pneumonia + heart failure. Respiratory status improving
   clinically and radiographically. Mental status greatly improved this
   morning; RSBI in the 30
   - attempt extubation after TEE
   - f/u pending cultures
   - f/u bronch data
   .
   # Chronic systolic heart failure: Patient with EF 20-25%. Has been
   diuresing well to lasix boluses.
   - continue to monitor fluid status
   - continue metoprolol [**Hospital1 7**]
   - lasix boluses for goal I/O negative 1 L; will give 60 mg IV lasix now
   .
   # Elevated CK: Likely caused by stain (possibly exacerbated by
   concurrent azithromycin therapy).  CK trending down.
   - continue to trend CK
   - no further IV fluids at this point, as CK not at a significant enough
   level to cause renal failure
   - holding statin
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt has a history of an anterior wall MI in [**2126**]. Of note,
   the patient did report some chest pressure previously, but this has
   since resolved.  MI ruled out with 3 sets of cardiac enzymes.
   - continue aspirin, simvastatin, metoprolol
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation: Pt with a history of a.fib, for which he is on
   coumadin. His INR is currently near therapeutic. Telemetry currently
   showing v-paced rhythm.
   - metoprolol [**Hospital1 7**]
   - increase Coumadin; trend INR
   - starting heparin gtt bridge while subtherapeutic INR
   .
   # s/p ICD: high impedance. LV lead dysfunction. Of note, ICD did not
   shock patient during code blue yesterday.
   -pacer revision in future
   -TEE to look for lead endocarditis, as above
   -if develops VT, will need external therapy as ICD is not functioning
   .
   # Hypothyroidism:
   - continue levothyroxine 50 mcg daily
   .
   # Anemia: Pt with a history of anemia, baseline Hct of approx. 33-35.
   Hct gradually trending down. No evidence of bleeding.
   - continue iron supplementation
   - continue to trend hct
   .
   # S/p Whipple: On tube feeds.
   - Holding pancreatic enzyme supplementation while on tube feeds.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin Sliding Scale

The patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation, who presented to the emergency department with dyspnea initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia. 

The patient's current condition shows improvement in respiratory status, mental status, and fever. However, he has a positive blood culture for Gram-positive cocci (GPC) this morning. This could represent a true infection or contaminant. The plan is to continue meropenem and add vancomycin in the setting of positive blood culture. 

The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure was initially managed with intubation due to severe hypoxemia. The etiology was likely pneumonia and heart failure. His respiratory status has been improving clinically and radiographically. Mental status has also greatly improved this morning. 

The patient has chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. He has been diuresing well to lasix boluses. 

Elevated CK levels are likely caused by statin therapy (possibly exacerbated by concurrent azithromycin therapy). The CK is trending down.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

1. The patient is a 71-year-old male with a medical history significant for systolic heart failure (EF 20-25%), myocardial infarction in [**26**], paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, history of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation after implantation of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), presenting to the emergency department with dyspnea initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia.

2. The patient was intubated on [**4-20**] for hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely caused by pneumonia and heart failure. He was extubated at 4 PM.

3. The patient had a positive blood culture for coag-negative Staphylococcus, which could represent a true infection or contaminant. He is being treated with meropenem and vancomycin.

4. The patient has chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. He has been diuresing well to Lasix boluses. His fluid status is being closely monitored.

5. The patient has elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels, which are trending down. This is likely caused by statin therapy. The statin has been held.

Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a significant past medical history including systolic heart failure (ejection fraction 20-25%), myocardial infarction in 2006, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation after implantation of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). He presented to the emergency department with dyspnea, initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia.

The patient was intubated on 3/4 for hypoxemia, likely secondary to pneumonia and heart failure. His respiratory status has improved clinically and radiographically. Mental status has also greatly improved this morning, and he is now extubated. His fever has resolved, and blood cultures are pending. Bronchoscopic data is also pending.

The patient continues to have chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. He has been diuresing well to lasix boluses. His CK level is elevated but trending down and is likely caused by statin therapy. The patient has a history of an anterior wall myocardial infarction in 2006 and is on aspirin, simvastatin, and metoprolol.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is on coumadin with an INR near therapeutic range. Te

   71 y/o M with PMHx significant for systolic HF (EF 20-25%), MI in '[**26**],
   paroxysmal AV block, atrial fibrillation, h/o v.tach and v.fib s/p ICD
   implantation, who presented to the ED with a chief complaint of
   dyspnea, initially thought to be due to CHF exacerbation with
   infiltrate, fever, white count consistent with PNA.
   .
   # Fever/Pneumonia: Now afebrile x 48 hours. Previously, patient was
   spiking high fevers in spite of Tylenol, antibiotics, and improvement
   of pneumonia. This led to concern about an occult infection or
   non-infectious cause of fever. CT abd/pelvis and CT sinuses were
   negative. TEE showed no vegetation. There was one positive blood cx
   (coag neg staph). This could represent true infection versus
   contaminant.
   - continue meropenem/vanc
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u pending microbiological studies
   .
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Now s/p extubation. Was intubated on
   [**4-20**] for hypoxemic respiratory failure. Etiology likely pneumonia
   + heart failure.
   - f/u pending cultures
   - treat pneumonia as above
   .
   # Chronic systolic heart failure: Patient with EF 20-25%. Has been
   diuresing well to lasix boluses.
   - continue to monitor fluid status
   - continue metoprolol [**Hospital1 7**]
   - lasix boluses for goal I/O negative 1 L
   .
   # Elevated CK: Likely caused by stain (possibly exacerbated by
   concurrent azithromycin therapy).  CK trending down.
   - holding statin
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt has a history of an anterior wall MI in [**2126**]. Of note,
   the patient did report some chest pressure previously, but this has
   since resolved.  MI ruled out with 3 sets of cardiac enzymes.
   - continue aspirin, metoprolol
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation: Pt with a history of a.fib, for which he is on
   coumadin. His INR is currently near therapeutic. Telemetry currently
   showing v-paced rhythm.
   - metoprolol [**Hospital1 7**]
   - holding Coumadin; started heparin gtt in anticipation of possible EP
   procedure
   .
   # s/p ICD: high impedance. LV lead dysfunction. Of note, ICD did not
   shock patient during VT/VF arrest.
   -f/u EP recs
   -if develops VT, will need external therapy as ICD is not functioning
   .
   # Hypothyroidism:

   # Anemia: Pt with a history of anemia, baseline Hct of approx. 33-35.

   - continue iron supplementation

   # S/p Whipple: On tube feeds.

   71 y/o M with PMHx significant for systolic HF (EF 20-25%), MI in '[**26**],
   paroxysmal AV block, atrial fibrillation, h/o v.tach and v.fib s/p ICD
   implantation, who presented to the ED with a chief complaint of
   dyspnea, initially thought to be due to CHF exacerbation with
   infiltrate, fever, white count consistent with PNA.
   .
   # s/p VT/VF arrest/ICD dysfunction: Patient had VT/VF arrest on [**3-12**]
   during which ICD failed to defibrillate him and he required external
   therapy.  Patient had multiple runs of VT, including second VT arrest
   last night requiring defibrillation.  Etiology of recently increased
   ectopy is unclear.
   -f/u EP recs
   -[**Hospital1 1896**] pads in place
   -if develops VT, will need external therapy as ICD is not functioning
   -decrease amiodarone to 200 mg daily due to concern about prolonged QT
   -increase metoprolol to 25 mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hypoxia: Patient was intubated from [**Date range (1) 14185**] for hypoxemic
   respiratory failure. Etiology likely pneumonia + heart failure. Prior
   to last night
s VT arrest, patient was satting well on 2L NC. Has had
   increased O2 requirement since, possibly related to aspiration or
   worsening heart failure.
   -aspiration precautions
   -f/u speech and swallow recs
   -diurese for goal negative 1 L today
   .
   # Altered mental status: Disorientation, waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 533**], reversal of
   sleep/wake cycle characteristic of delirium. Etiology is likely recent
   intubation (with sedating meds) and ICU environment. No focal
   neurologic deficits.
   - continue to follow clinically
   - minimize sedating medications
   .
   # Fever/Pneumonia: Now afebrile for several days. Previously, patient
   was spiking high fevers in spite of Tylenol, antibiotics, and
   improvement of pneumonia. This led to concern about an occult infection
   or non-infectious cause of fever. CT abd/pelvis and CT sinuses were
   negative. TEE showed no vegetation. There was one positive blood cx
   (coag neg staph). This could represent true infection versus
   contaminant.
   - continue cefpodoxime
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u pending microbiological studies
   .
   # Chronic systolic heart failure: Patient with EF 20-25%. Has been
   diuresing well to lasix boluses.
   - continue to monitor fluid status
   - continue metoprolol [**Hospital1 7**]
   - goal negative 1 L today
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR markedly elevated today. Likely related to
   amiodarone.
   -continue to hold Coumadin
   -vitamin K 2 mg PO once
   .
   # Elevated CK: Likely caused by stain (possibly exacerbated by
   concurrent azithromycin therapy).  CK trending down.
   - holding statin
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt has a history of an anterior wall MI in [**2126**]. Of note,
   the patient did report some chest pressure previously, but this has
   since resolved.  MI ruled out with 3 sets of cardiac enzymes.
   - continue aspirin, metoprolol
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation: Pt with a history of a.fib, for which he is on
   coumadin.
   - metoprolol [**Hospital1 7**]
   - holding Coumadin; started heparin gtt in anticipation of possible EP
   procedure
   .
   # Hypothyroidism:
   - continue levothyroxine 50 mcg daily
   .
   # Anemia: Pt with a history of anemia, baseline Hct of approx. 33-35.
   Hct gradually trending down. No evidence of bleeding.
   - continue iron supplementation
   - continue to trend hct
   .
   # S/p Whipple: On tube feeds.
   - Holding pancreatic enzyme supplementation for now. Will need to
   restart enzyme supplementation if patient is cleared by speech and
   swallow.
   ICU Care

   off on feeding tube for now.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a medical history of systolic heart failure (ejection fraction 20-25%), myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation, post implantation of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). He presented to the emergency department with dyspnea, initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. ICD Dysfunction: The patient experienced a ventricular tachycardia (VT) arrest during which the ICD failed to defibrillate him and he required external therapy. There have been multiple runs of VT, including a second VT arrest last night requiring defibrillation. The etiology of the recently increased ectopy is unclear.

2. Hypoxia: The patient was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure. The etiology likely includes pneumonia and heart failure. Prior to the last night's VT arrest, the patient was saturating well on 2 liters nasal cannula (NC). He has had increased O2 requirement since, possibly related to aspiration or worsening heart failure.

3. Altered Mental Status: The patient is disoriented, experiencing waxing and waning consciousness, and has a reversal of sleep/wake cycle characteristic of delirium.

The patient has been advised to remain NPO (nothing by mouth) except for medications, with aspiration precautions. Blood and sputum cultures have been sent, and allergies to penicillins and Ambien have been noted.

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus who was admitted to the ICU for acute decompensated heart failure. The patient had been afebrile all day but experienced a sudden spike in temperature to 101.8 degrees Fahrenheit at around 10 PM. Vital signs were otherwise stable, although the patient appeared agitated. He was pan-cultured, given a one-time dose of meropenem for suspected aspiration pneumonitis or pneumonia, and a chest X-ray was ordered for morning rounds.

The patient's creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels increased, leading to maxed diuresis. Amiodarone was decreased, and metoprolol was increased per EP recommendations. The patient's ventricular tachycardia could have been terminated by ATP, so the pacer was set at a higher rate of 75-100 beats per minute to avoid fast-slow-fast sequences. ATP was also added in a FVT zone of 260-300 and DVT zone of 300-400.

The patient was advised to remain NPO except for medications and follow aspiration precautions. Blood and sputum cultures were sent. The patient has allergies to penicillins, hives, rash, and Ambien. His last dose of antibiotics was vancomycin on 03/15/2141 at 08:00 PM, and meropenem on 03

   infiltrate, fever, white count consistent with PNA.
   .

   during which ICD failed to defibrillate him and he required external

   .

   respiratory failure. Etiology likely pneumonia + heart failure. Prior
   to last night
s VT arrest, patient was satting well on 2L NC. Has had

   worsening heart failure.
   -aspiration precautions

   .

   - continue to follow clinically

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, infarct-related cardiomyopathy, and previous ventricular tachycardia (VT) treated with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). He presented to the emergency department with dyspnea and was found to have pneumonia with a chest infiltrate, fever, and leukocytosis. He was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient also has chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. He experienced episodes of pulseless VT requiring defibrillation and CPR. His ICD dysfunctioned during the VT/VF arrest, and he required external therapy. The patient is currently delirious, hypoxic, and febrile, with a recent spike in temperature. His renal function is worsening, and he has an elevated creatinine and BUN. His potassium levels are also elevated. He is on multiple medications including amiodarone, metoprolol, lasix, and heparin. The patient's recent hospital course has been complicated by several issues, including VT/VF arrest, hypoxia, delirium, pneumonia, and worsening renal function.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventricular Tachycardia (VT): The patient has a history of VT, which has recently recurred, requiring defibrillation and CPR. The cause of the VT is unclear. The patient

Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, previous myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) implantation. He presented to the emergency department with dyspnea, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia. The patient had a ventricular tachycardia (VT) arrest during which the ICD failed to defibrillate him and he required external therapy. He also had multiple runs of VT, including a second VT arrest last night requiring defibrillation. The patient was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. He developed a fever, which is now controlled with antibiotics. The patient's mental status has been altered since intubation, and he has been diagnosed with delirium. His heart failure has been managed with diuretics, and he has been on a ventilator due to hypoxia.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Ventricular tachycardia (VT): The patient has experienced multiple episodes of VT, which can be life-threatening if not properly managed.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's presentation with fever, white count, and infiltrates on chest X-ray suggests pneumonia, which can worsen his respiratory status and increase the risk of complications.
3. Heart failure: The patient has chronic systolic heart failure, and his condition may

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient, a 71-year-old male with a history of CAD, MI, HF, atrial fibrillation, and ICD implantation, presented to the ED with dyspnea and was initially thought to be due to CHF exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with PNA.
- The patient was initially on meropenem for concern of resistant klebsiella but became cx negative, and the antibiotic regimen was narrowed to suppressive cefpodoxime.
- The patient's temperature spiked again, and meropenem was restarted.
- The patient had an episode of pulseless VT requiring defibrillation and CPR, and amiodarone was reduced for concern of prolonged QT.
- The patient continues to be intermittently confused but conversant.
- The patient has a history of systolic HF (EF 20-25%), MI in [**26**], paroxysmal AV block, atrial fibrillation, h/o VT/VF s/p ICD implantation.
- The patient's ICD dysfunction includes LV lead not pacing, RV lead pacing, and a sensed V paced.
- The patient's hypoxia is likely due to pneumonia and heart failure, possibly related to aspiration.
- The patient's altered mental status is likely due to recent intubation and ICU environment.
- The patient's fever/pneumonia has been improving, but there are concerns about an occult infection or non-infect

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation. He presented to the emergency department with dyspnea and was initially thought to have a heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate. The patient also had a fever and white blood cell count consistent with pneumonia initially on meropenem for concern of resistant Klebsiella. However, the patient was later found to be culture-negative, and the antibiotic regimen was narrowed to suppressive cefpodoxime. The patient's temperature spiked again, and meropenem was restarted.

The patient experienced a ventricular tachycardia arrest on [Date] due to pacing settings. He required external therapy for ventricular fibrillation two nights ago. The etiology of the recent ectopy is thought to be fast/short sequences, and the pacing settings were adjusted accordingly. The patient's ICD may not be able to detect ventricular tachycardia/ventricular fibrillation. If the patient develops ventricular tachycardia, he will need external therapy as the ICD is not functioning properly. Possible lead extraction next week for RV coil fracture was mentioned.

The patient was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely due to pneumonia and heart failure. Prior to the ventricular arrest

Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a significant medical history including systolic heart failure, myocardial infarction, paroxysmal atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation. The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea and was initially thought to have a congestive heart failure exacerbation with infiltrate, fever, and white count consistent with pneumonia. He was started on meropenem for concern of resistant Klebsiella, but the culture was negative. The patient also had a ventricular tachycardia arrest, which required external therapy. He is currently in the ICU, intubated, and on mechanical ventilation due to hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient has had intermittent periods of lucidity and is suspected to have delirium. His mental status has improved with orientation to person and place. He has been diuresing well with furosemide, showing improvement in the chest X-ray and oxygenation. The patient's fever resolved, but recently spiked again, leading to the restart of meropenem. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: The patient initially presented with symptoms suggestive of pneumonia, including fever, white count elevation, and infiltrate on chest X-ray. Although the initial culture was negative, the patient's recent fever spike could indicate a possible recurrence or another infectious process.

   subsequently attributed to pneumonia in setting of infiltrate, fever,

   # VT/VF/ICD dysfunction: Patient had VT/VF arrest on [**3-12**] during which
   ICD failed to defibrillate him and he required external therapy.
   Subsequently, patient has had multiple runs of VT, including one VT
   arrest which required external defibrillation. Etiology of recent
   increased ectopy thought to be [**1-24**] fast/short sequences, pacer
   settings, and QT prolongation in setting of amiodarone. RV coil

   respiratory failure. Etiology likely pneumonia + heart failure. Prior
   to second arrest, patient was satting well on 2L NC. Had increased O2
   requirement after arrest, thought to be related to aspiration
   pneumonitis, but now satting well on 2L NC. Heart failure less likely
   etiology of hypoxia.

The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea, initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation but subsequently attributed to pneumonia in the setting of infiltrate, fever, and white count. 

During the hospital course, the patient experienced high fevers, ICD malfunction, ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation arrest requiring defibrillation and reintubation, and runs of ventricular tachycardia, including one ventricular tachycardia arrest. The etiology of recent increased ectopy is thought to be fast/short sequences, pacer settings, and QT prolongation in the setting of amiodarone. The right ventricular coil fractured. 

The patient's current medical issues include VT/VF/ICD dysfunction, hypoxia, altered mental status, fever/pneumonia, chronic systolic heart failure, hypernatremia, elevated creatine kinase (CK), coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, hypothyroidism, anemia, and post Whipple's procedure.

   71 y/o M with PMHx significant for systolic HF (EF 20-25%), MI in '[**26**],
   paroxysmal AV block, atrial fibrillation, h/o v.tach and v.fib s/p ICD
   implantation, who presented to the ED with a chief complaint of
   dyspnea, initially thought to be due to CHF exacerbation but
   subsequently attributed to pneumonia in setting of infiltrate, fever,
   white count. Hospital course complicated by high fevers, ICD
   malfunction, VT/VF arrest requiring debrillation and reintubation, and
   runs of VT, including one VT arrest.
   .
   # VT/VF/ICD dysfunction: Patient had VT/VF arrest on [**3-12**] during which
   ICD failed to defibrillate him and he required external therapy.
   Subsequently, patient has had multiple runs of VT, including one VT
   arrest which required external defibrillation. Etiology of recent
   increased ectopy thought to be [**1-24**] fast/short sequences, pacer
   settings, and QT prolongation in setting of amiodarone. RV coil
   fractured.
   -f/u EP recs regarding need for EP procedure/ICD revision
   -continue current amnio dose 200mg daily,  metoprololl 25mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   -monitor QTC on EKG
   -continue Telemetry
   -if develops VT, will need external therapy as ICD is not functioning
   .
   # Hypoxia: Patient was intubated from [**Date range (1) 14185**] for hypoxemic
   respiratory failure. Etiology likely pneumonia + heart failure. Prior
   to second arrest, patient was satting well on 2L NC. Had increased O2
   requirement after arrest, thought to be related to aspiration
   pneumonitis, but now satting well on 2L NC. Heart failure less likely
   etiology of hypoxia.
   -aspiration precautions
   -f/u speech and swallow recs
   -wean O2 as tolerated
   -restart home dose of PO Lasix
   -no abx for now (except cefpodoxime, which patient takes chronically as
   outpt) as patient was felt to have aspiration pneumonitis rather than
   true pneumonia
   .
   # Altered mental status: Disorientation, waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 533**], reversal of
   sleep/wake cycle characteristic of delirium. Etiology is likely recent
   intubation (with sedating meds) and ICU environment. No focal
   neurologic deficits. Pt has had marked improvement in past 2 day.
   - continue to follow clinically
   - minimize sedating medications
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cr transiently increased in setting of diruesis
   with IV lasix, now back to baseline. Likely pre-renal.
   - trend Cr
   .
   # Fever/Pneumonia: Now afebrile. Previously, patient was spiking high
   fevers in spite of Tylenol, antibiotics, and improvement of pneumonia.
   This led to concern about an occult infection or non-infectious cause
   of fever. CT abd/pelvis and CT sinuses were negative. TEE showed no
   vegetation. There was one positive blood cx (coag neg staph). This

   - f/u ID recs

   -continue to hold Coumadin until below 2.0 then restart.
   -continue to trend.
   .

   concurrent azithromycin therapy).  CK trending down.
   - holding statin

He presented to the emergency department with dyspnea initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation but subsequently attributed to pneumonia. The hospital course has been complicated by high fevers, ICD malfunction, ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation arrest requiring defibrillation, reintubation, and runs of VT including one VT arrest.

1. VT/VF/ICD Dysfunction: The patient experienced ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation arrests and required external therapy due to ICD malfunction. There are plans to follow up with electrophysiology recommendations regarding the need for an electrophysiology procedure and ICD revision.
2. Hypoxia: The patient was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure likely due to pneumonia and heart failure. After the second arrest, the patient's oxygen requirement increased, but now he is tolerating 2 liters of nasal cannula oxygen well, making heart failure less likely as the etiology of hypoxia.

The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation but later attributed to pneumonia in the setting of infiltrate, fever, and white blood cell count. The hospital course has been complicated by high fevers despite Tylenol and meropenem, runs of VT, ICD malfunction, ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation arrest requiring defibrillation, and rapid VT requiring defibrillation. The patient also had ventricular tachycardia thought to be fast/short sequences due to pacer setting. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure due to pneumonia and possibly heart failure. He has had increased O2 requirement since, requiring a face mask and desaturation when not on it, possibly related to aspiration, less likely worsening heart failure.

The patient presented to the emergency department with dyspnea initially thought to be due to congestive heart failure exacerbation but was subsequently attributed to pneumonia in the setting of infiltrate, fever, and white count. The hospital course has been complicated by high fevers, ICD malfunction, ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation arrest requiring defibrillation and reintubation, and runs of ventricular tachycardia, including one ventricular tachycardia arrest.

   71 y/o M with PMHx significant for systolic HF (EF 20-25%), MI in '[**26**],
   paroxysmal AV block, atrial fibrillation, h/o v.tach and v.fib s/p ICD
   implantation, who presented to the ED with a chief complaint of
   dyspnea, initially thought to be due to CHF exacerbation but
   subsequently attributed to pneumonia in setting of infiltrate, fever,
   white count. Hospital course complicated by high fevers, ICD
   malfunction, VT/VF arrest requiring debrillation and reintubation, and
   runs of VT, including one VT arrest.
   .
   # VT/VF/ICD dysfunction: Patient had VT/VF arrest on [**3-12**] during which
   ICD failed to defibrillate him and he required external therapy.
   Subsequently, patient has had multiple runs of VT, including one VT
   arrest which required external defibrillation. Etiology of recent
   increased ectopy thought to be [**1-24**] fast/short sequences, pacer
   settings, and QT prolongation in setting of amiodarone. RV coil was
   found to be fractured.
   -Tentative plans for ICD revision on Thursday pending patient and
   family are in agreement
   -f/u EP recs regarding need for EP procedure/ICD revision
   -continue current amiodarone dose 200mg daily,  metoprolol 25mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   -monitor QTC on EKG
   -continue Telemetry
   -if develops VT, will need external therapy as ICD is not functioning
   .
   # Hypoxia: Patient was intubated from [**Date range (1) 14185**] for hypoxemic
   respiratory failure. Etiology likely pneumonia + heart failure. Prior
   to second arrest, patient was satting well on 2L NC. Had increased O2
   requirement after arrest, thought to be related to aspiration
   pneumonitis, but now satting well on 2L NC. This is still above
   baseline as he does not usually use supplemental oxygen.  Heart failure
   less likely etiology of hypoxia and received home dose PO lasix this
   am.  Speech and swallow evaluated this am and recommend PNO for now
   except meds with repeat video swallow study.
   -aspiration precautions
   -Video swallow study
   - F/u speech and swallow recs based on results of video, but for now
   NPO except meds
   -wean O2 as tolerated
   -continue home dose of PO Lasix
   -check PM Is/Os
 if not 1 to 1.5 L negative will give one dose IV 40
   mg lasix as yesterday pt required extra IV dose
   -no abx for now (except cefpodoxime, which patient takes chronically as
   outpt) as patient was felt to have aspiration pneumonitis rather than
   true pneumonia and ABX course completed for PNA.
   .
   # Altered mental status: Disorientation, waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 533**], reversal of
   sleep/wake cycle characteristic of delirium. Etiology is likely recent
   intubation (with sedating meds) and ICU environment. No focal
   neurologic deficits. Pt has had overall marked improvement in past 2
   days.
   - continue to follow clinically
   - minimize sedating medications
   .
   # Fever/Pneumonia: Now afebrile status post completed course of
   antibiotics. Previously, patient was spiking high fevers in spite of
   Tylenol, antibiotics, and improvement of pneumonia. This led to concern
   about an occult infection or non-infectious cause of fever. CT
   abd/pelvis and CT sinuses were negative. TEE showed no vegetation.
   There was one positive blood cx (coag neg staph), thought to be a
   contaminant.  Patient was afebrile from [**Date range (1) 14227**], but spiked one fever
   to 101.8 thought to be related to possible aspiration pneumonitis in
   setting of recent arrest. Has been afebrile since.

   - no abx for now except chronic suppressive cefpodoxime therapy for
   history of device infection
   .
   # Chronic systolic heart failure: Patient with EF 20-25%. Currently
   euvolemic.
   - continue PO Lasix at home dose

   - continue metoprolol [**Hospital1 7**]
   .

   - patient was given free water with D5W last night and sodium slightly

   .

   since resolved.  MI ruled out with 3 sets of cardiac enzymes.
   - continue aspirin, metoprolol

   .
   # Hypothyroidism:

   .

   - continue iron supplementation
